This is a known issue. Please see the README file at /eclipse/readme/readme.html.

In general we restrict the names of the resources that a user can create for the
case where the files are shared on a repository and shared with other
developers. This way you don't run into problems when you create a file on Linux
(with a valid char) and then try and load it in Windows (where the char is invalid).

The readme talks about starting eclipse and classpath issues, which is not the
same as this.

I haven't created the file via eclipse - I am trying to point eclipse at an
existing project structure that has a directory name with a colon in it. 

This is still a bug, because Eclipse doesn't give me any kind of sensible
warning. A dialog telling me that it has found a file or directory with a colon
in, and that it doesn't like this is would be a good deal better than 

"Internal error: path must include project and resource name:/Test"

and an IllegalArgumentException in the log file. It created the project in a
broken state, and it took me a good while to find out what was causing the problem.

The colon in the filename isn't going away any time soon, as it is created as
part of the project's build. So I can't use Eclipse for this project.

Even better would be a warning about such files potentially giving
cross-platform issues. If this isn't a problem (e.g. everyone is using *nix
systems), then there should be an option to disable the warning. the choice
should be left up to the user.

> This way you don't run into problems when you create a file on Linux
(with a valid char) and then try and load it in Windows 

I find this quite an odd thing to enforce. If Eclipse will not accept valid
paths on Unix systems then it cannot be used for some projects.  Surely it is up
to the dev team to cope with this kind of problem?  

Even if the path issue were to be left as is, it is not acceptable for Eclipse
to fail in the way it does when invalid paths are present in an existing
projects structure.
This looks to me to be very closely related to Bug 61761

If the behaviour of the resource handling code is not going to be changed, then
how about fixing the error message, and making the workbench handle the error in
a more graceful manner, so a broken project isn't left lying about. 

How about I raise a new bug for this behaviour?
